hobby.message: Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Feels more like static than a storm, if you ask me.
Mostly just kept to myself today, stayed indoors.
Tried a bit of origami—helps pass the time.
Surveillance makes even folding paper feel… observed lately.
Could say that. Everyone’s on display lately, right?
I fold origami models. Quiet thing, keeps my hands from fidgeting.
Made something small from a kiosk flyer—couldn’t really concentrate, though.
Wildcard BCI glitches made me second-guess even harmless hobbies.
Feels like the walls have eyes and memories now.
Hard not to notice; people are acting rehearsed, like someone’s watching every move.
I unwind by folding paper—origami, mostly complex tessellations or modular pieces.
Used old compliance notices for the last ones—plenty of material now.
Yesterday, I hesitated mid-fold, thinking—could this get flagged as eccentric?
That thought never crossed my mind before the glitches started.
Hobbies like mine, they’re supposed to relax you, not feel like a risk.
Yeah, tension’s thick. Saw my neighbor sweeping the hall for the third time, all performance.
I fold intricate origami—keeps me sane, usually relieves stress after work.
Been using government scraps, old BCI reports—they’re everywhere these days.
Lately, even at home, it feels like every crease has eyes on it.
Last night, my comm flashed a system appreciation prompt and I lost my rhythm.
Doesn’t help knowing my BCI dropped after a late night folding session.
Before all this, it was just paper and peace—no second-guessing.
Calling it a storm almost sounds quaint compared to this.
Origami’s my anchor—folding tessellations, complex modular models, whatever’s at hand.
Started with old bus tickets, now I use surveillance memos and compliance printouts.
I’ve kept a log of every model, from pre-BCI calm to now; you can see the shift.
During last night’s forced appreciation window, I paused mid-fold, terrified an algorithm was watching.
Sometimes I test if shifting crease patterns change how the flat scans interpret my movements.
It’s strange: a year ago, I never thought a quiet hobby could make me feel like a liability.
No one warns you how easily normal gets rewritten in this city.
hobby_answer: Yeah, something simple, nothing fancy tonight.
It's...just paper. Keeps my hands busy, that's all.
I don't try anything that stands out much lately.
Feels like everyone's watching, after all the last few days.
Hard to relax when things are so tight out there.
Just a quick fold, barely even practiced.
Used to do more complex models—now I keep it plain.
They say compliance is easier when your hobbies are 'normal.'
All the patrols outside kind of suck the fun out of it.
Last night, I kept the blinds shut, didn't even finish.
Funny, even folding paper can feel like a risk these days.
Yeah, always one in my pocket—habit at this point.
I folded a corrugated tessellation from a receipt yesterday.
These days, I stick to neutral shapes. No cranes or anything too whimsical.
Patrols were everywhere when I got home—hard not to notice.
The window light makes me nervous, like even origami needs to be performative now.
I’ve seen people scrubbing corners twice, just for display.
Feels like the city itself is folding into something tighter, you know?
Got a new fold, actually—a polygon twist, nothing too flashy.
Long day, so I used a scrap compliance reminder for paper.
I like complex patterns, but lately, I’m second-guessing every crease.
After all that drama—street patrols, compliance displays—it’s hard to focus.
I half-finished one last night because the compliance message popped up.
Little things like origami, they feel exposed now, like the system's scraping even those.
Saw my neighbor orchestrating 'spontaneous' garbage sorting—can’t tell what’s real anymore.
Paper folding is supposed to clear my head, but the tension sticks.
Brought a crease pattern, actually—modular tessellation, made from old access forms.
Started folding in university, helps me process patterns, stress, all of it.
When the city turns performative, every habit gets scrutinized, even hobbies.
Used to fold at my window—now it's all public visibility. Doesn't feel safe.
Patrol boots echo outside my block every hour lately.
Even my comm tablet sent a 'system appreciation' alert mid-fold yesterday.
Sometimes I finish a model, sometimes I stop—paranoia gets in the way.
People force routines just to look compliant, but it’s all artificial calm.
Origami’s meant to soothe, but now it’s just another thing that feels...watched.
